(September 1989) | Misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|h3Yrhv33Zb8|"Love In An Elevator"}}}} }} "'''Love in an Elevator'''" is a song performed by [[People of the United States|American]] [[hard rock]] band [[Aerosmith]], written by [[Steven Tyler]] and [[guitarist]]/[[backing vocalist]] [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]]. It was released in August 1989 as the lead [[Single (music)|single]] from their third album with [[Geffen Records]], ''[[Pump (album)|Pump]]'', released in September (see [[1989 in music]]). It peaked at number 5 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and reached number 1 on the [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] chart.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=aerosmith-p3508/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}} |title=Aerosmith - Billboard Singles |work=Allmusic |publisher=Rovi Corporation |accessdate=November 21, 2010}} ==Track listings== ===7" 45 RPM=== {{Track listing | writing_credits = yes | headline = Side One | title1 = Love in an Elevator | writer1 = [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]], [[Steven Tyler]] }} {{Track listing | writing_credits = yes | headline = Side Two | title1 = Young Lust | writer1 = Tyler, Perry, [[Jim Vallance]] }} ===CD single=== {{Track listing | writing_credits = yes | title1 = Love in an Elevator | note1 = Edit | writer1 = Perry, Tyler | length1 = 3:42 | title2 = Ain't Enough | writer2 = Perry, Tyler | length2 = 5:03 | title3 = Young Lust | note3 = LP Version | writer3 = Tyler, Perry, Jim Vallance | length3 = 4:22 }} ==Recording== "Love in an Elevator", like the other tracks on ''Pump'', was recorded sometime in April to June 1989 at [[Little Mountain Sound Studios]] in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. During the writing process, lead singer Steven Tyler is said to have come upon the concept of the song while researching famous battleships. Specifically, an instance on the Russian battleship ''Navarin'', in which one of the crew was famously quoted, as the ship was going down, "Мы должны жить вверх, в то время как мы теперь идем вниз," or when translated "we must live upwards now, for it is downward we head." Tyler claims the song's lyrics were inspired by an experience he had at a hotel, in which he was making out with a girl in the elevator and they started having sex as the doors opened; “It felt like a lifetime waiting for those doors to close,” quipped Tyler. The song was [[Record producer|produced]] by [[Bruce Fairbairn]] and was [[Audio engineering|engineered]] by [[Mike Fraser (record producer)|Mike Fraser]] with Ken Lomas as second engineer, and in addition to Aerosmith – [[Steven Tyler]] ([[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]]), [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]] ([[guitar]]s, [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]]), [[Brad Whitford]] (guitars, backing vocals), [[Tom Hamilton (musician)|Tom Hamilton]] ([[Bass guitar|electric bass]], backing vocals), and [[Joey Kramer]] ([[Drum kit|drum]]s, [[Percussion instrument|percussion]]) – were Bob Dowd (backing vocals), [[Bruce Fairbairn]] (backing vocals), and Catherine Epps (elevator operator). ==Chart performance== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !scope="col"|Chart (1989) !scope="col"|Peak
position |- |Australia (Top 50){{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Aerosmith&titel=Love+In+An+Elevator&cat=s |title=Aerosmith - Love In An Elevator |publisher=australian-charts.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-09}} |style="text-align:center;"|33 |- |Canada (''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]''100 Singles){{cite web |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.6575&type=2&interval=20&PHPSESSID=m89iq841abagb37ld9c0fdc1f3 |title=RPM - Item Display: Top Singles - Volume 51, No. 2, November 11 1989 |date=March 31, 2004 |work=[[Library and Archives Canada]] |format=.Php }} |style="text-align:center;"|13 |- {{singlechart |Dutch100|14|song=Love In An Elevator|artist=Aerosmith}} |- {{singlechart |New Zealand|15|song=Love In An Elevator|artist=Aerosmith}} |- |align='left'|[[Polish Singles Chart]]{{cite web|url=http://lp3.polskieradio.pl/notowania/?numer=409 |title=Polish Singles Chart |publisher=Lp3.polskieradio.pl |date=1989-12-23 |accessdate=2012-09-09}} | style="text-align:center;"|15 |- {{singlechart |UK|13|song=Love in an Elevator|artist=Aerosmith|date=1989-09-30}} |- |US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] |style="text-align:center;"|5 |- |US ''Billboard'' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] |style="text-align:center;"|1 |} ===End of Year Chart=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !align="left"|End of year chart (1989) ! style="text-align:center;"|Position |- |U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot 100{{cite web|url=http://longboredsurfer.com/charts/1989.php|title=Billboard Top 100 - 1989|accessdate=2010-02-09}} | style="text-align:center;"|81 |} ==Music video== The video for the song, considered by many to be a definitive music video for Aerosmith, starts off with the band walking up to a department store elevator, and an attractive woman ([[Brandi Brandt]]) says "2nd floor...hardware, children's wear, lady's lingerie. Oh, good morning Mr. Tyler, going down?" Steven Tyler enters the elevator and the song starts. The video flashes back and forth between the band performing live and scenes from the department store. The scenes in the department store and elevator include Brad Whitford being hypnotized by fake department store models turning into real ones when he's not looking, Joey Kramer dressed up like a woman, Joe Perry and his wife (both topless) kissing in the elevator, Tyler kissing the female department store clerk, and [[Tom Hamilton (musician)|Tom Hamilton]] playing his bass grooves, in addition to the odd performances of other random characters, including a butcher, a fat lady, midgets, the [[Tin Woodman|Tin Man]] and [[Dorothy Gale]] from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (adaptations)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', and a male model. At the end of the song, all the band members gather around the microphone to sing "Love in an Elevator...lovin' it up when I'm going down". And then it flashes back to a scene in which the elevator doors close. The video was directed by [[Marty Callner]], who produced many of the band's Geffen-era music videos in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The woman with the male little person in the video is Dee Booher, better known as Queen Kong in the Los Angeles area. She also wrestled on TV show [[Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling|''G.L.O.W.'']] as Matilda the Hun. ==In concert== The song has consistently been a staple in the band's setlist on almost every tour they have performed since the song's release. It is a fan favorite and is well-known among mainstream audiences. Also, in concert, Tyler often changes the lyrics to more controversial and profanity-laden ones. On a version of the song featured on the live album ''[[A Little South of Sanity]]'', culled from the band's tours in the 1990s, one can hear Tyler say "jackin' in the elevator" and "lick your funky ass" or "fucking ass" instead of "kiss your sassafras". ==Use in Disney World rollercoaster== A portion of the song plays within the ride sequence of [[Walt Disney World]]'s [[Rock 'n Roller Coaster]] ride, which features different Aerosmith songs on each of its ride vehicles. The lyrics for the Disney World version were specially revised to say "Love in a roller coaster" at the end of the ride. ==Reception== ===Award nomination=== The song received a Grammy award nomination in 1990 for [[Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal|Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal]], but lost out to supergroup [[The Traveling Wilburys]]. ==References== ==External links== *{{Discogs master |37106 |Love In An Elevator|type=single }} {{Aerosmith singles}} [[Category:Aerosmith songs]] [[Category:1989 singles]] [[Category:Music videos directed by Marty Callner]] [[Category:Billboard Mainstream Rock number-one singles]] [[Category:Songs written by Steven Tyler]] [[Category:Songs written by Joe Perry (musician)]] [[Category:Geffen Records singles]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Bruce Fairbairn]] [[Category:Elevators]] [[Category:1989 songs]] [[Category:Songs about sexuality]]
